scenario.title: Policy Fundamentals Deep Dive
scenario.remediation_focus: This scenario reinforces foundational concepts around security controls, policy hierarchy, and control categorization. Complete this if you struggled with policy-related questions in D1-SIM-001 or D1-SIM-005.

overview.situation: You've recently joined Coastal Community Bank as a junior GRC analyst. Your manager has noticed gaps in documentation and has assigned you to help rebuild the policy framework from the ground up. This is an opportunity to learn the fundamentals while contributing real value.
overview.your_role: Junior GRC Analyst - Policy Development Team
overview.mission: Learn and apply security policy fundamentals including control categories, policy hierarchy, and framework alignment while developing documentation for the bank.

company_context.name: Coastal Community Bank
company_context.infrastructure: Core banking platform (vendor-hosted), Microsoft 365, on-premise servers for legacy systems
company_context.recent_events: Examiner findings cited 'inadequate policy documentation' in last audit

artifacts.title: Policy Hierarchy Reference
artifacts.content:
SECURITY DOCUMENTATION HIERARCHY

1. POLICIES (What and Why)
   - High-level statements of intent
   - Approved by executive leadership
   - Changed infrequently (annual review)
   - Example: 'All data must be classified and protected according to its sensitivity'

2. STANDARDS (What specifically)
   - Specific mandatory requirements
   - Defines measurable criteria
   - Example: 'Passwords must be minimum 12 characters with complexity'

3. PROCEDURES (How)
   - Step-by-step instructions
   - Operational guidance
   - Example: 'To reset a password: 1) Navigate to... 2) Click... 3) Enter...'

4. GUIDELINES (Suggestions)
   - Recommended practices
   - Non-mandatory guidance
   - Example: 'Consider using a password manager to generate unique passwords'

KEY PRINCIPLE: Policies are enforced through standards; standards are implemented through procedures; guidelines provide optional best practices.

artifacts.title: Control Categories Reference
artifacts.content:
SECURITY CONTROL CATEGORIES

BY FUNCTION (What they do):

PREVENTIVE - Stop incidents before they happen
  Examples: Firewalls, access controls, encryption, security training

DETECTIVE - Identify incidents when they occur
  Examples: IDS, log monitoring, SIEM, audit trails, motion sensors

CORRECTIVE - Fix issues after detection
  Examples: Patch management, backup restoration, incident response

DETERRENT - Discourage threat actors
  Examples: Warning banners, security cameras, login notifications

COMPENSATING - Alternative controls when primary isn't feasible
  Examples: Increased monitoring when segmentation isn't possible

---

BY IMPLEMENTATION TYPE:

TECHNICAL (Logical) - Technology-based
  Examples: Firewalls, encryption, MFA, antivirus

ADMINISTRATIVE (Managerial) - People and process
  Examples: Policies, training, background checks, access reviews

PHYSICAL - Tangible protection
  Examples: Locks, fences, guards, badges, cameras

decision_points.title: Policy vs Standard vs Procedure
decision_points.context: Your manager hands you a document and asks you to identify what type it is. The document reads: 'Step 1: Log into the admin console at https://admin.coastalbank.com. Step 2: Navigate to User Management. Step 3: Select the user account. Step 4: Click 'Disable Account' and confirm.'
decision_points.question: What type of security document is this?

options.text: Policy - it's an official document about security
options.feedback: Not quite. Policies are high-level statements of intent (what and why), not step-by-step instructions. This document tells HOW to do something, not WHAT should be done or WHY.
options.consequence: Your manager asks you to reconsider - 'Would an executive approve step-by-step clicking instructions?'

options.text: Standard - it defines specific requirements
options.feedback: Close, but standards define WHAT must be done (specific requirements), not HOW to do it. A standard might say 'Terminated user accounts must be disabled within 24 hours.' This document shows the steps to achieve that.
options.consequence: Your manager explains the distinction between requirements (standards) and implementation steps (procedures).

options.text: Procedure - it provides step-by-step operational instructions
options.feedback: Correct! Procedures provide detailed, step-by-step instructions for HOW to accomplish tasks. They're operational documents that staff follow to implement standards. The numbered steps and specific UI navigation clearly identify this as a procedure.
options.consequence: Your manager confirms - 'Exactly right. Procedures tell us HOW to do things.'

options.text: Guideline - it's optional best practice advice
options.feedback: Guidelines are optional recommendations. This document appears to be mandatory operational instructions (disabling accounts is a required action, not optional). The prescriptive 'Step 1, Step 2' format indicates a required procedure.
options.consequence: Your manager notes that disabling terminated accounts isn't optional - it's required.

hints.text: Look at the format - numbered steps telling you exactly what to click. What document type provides 'how-to' instructions?
Policy = What/Why, Standard = What specifically, Procedure = How (step-by-step), Guideline = Suggestions

decision_points.learning_note: Memory aid: Policies answer 'What should we do and why?' Standards answer 'What exactly is required?' Procedures answer 'How do we do it?' Guidelines answer 'What's recommended but optional?'

decision_points.title: Control Function Classification
decision_points.context: You're reviewing controls and need to classify them by function. Your manager shows you this control: 'Security awareness training is provided to all employees annually covering phishing recognition, password security, and data handling.'
decision_points.question: What is the PRIMARY function of this control?

options.text: Detective - it helps identify security incidents
options.feedback: Detective controls identify incidents after or as they occur (like IDS, log monitoring, audit trails). Training happens before incidents - it's designed to stop employees from falling for attacks in the first place.
options.consequence: Consider: Does training detect incidents, or does it prevent them?

options.text: Preventive - it stops incidents before they happen
options.feedback: Correct! Security awareness training is preventive - it equips employees to recognize and avoid threats like phishing, preventing incidents from occurring. Trained employees don't click malicious links in the first place.
options.consequence: Your manager agrees - training prevents incidents by changing behavior before attacks succeed.

options.text: Corrective - it fixes issues after they're found
options.feedback: Corrective controls fix problems after detection (like patch management, backup restoration). Training is proactive - it happens before incidents, not in response to them.
options.consequence: Think about timing: When does training happen relative to incidents?

options.text: Compensating - it's an alternative when other controls fail
options.feedback: Compensating controls substitute for primary controls that aren't feasible. Training is a primary control in its own right, not a workaround. Every organization should have security awareness training as a baseline.
options.consequence: Training is a fundamental control, not a compensating alternative.

hints.text: Think about WHEN this control operates. Before incidents? During? After?
Preventive = stops threats before they succeed. A trained employee doesn't click phishing links.

decision_points.learning_note: Control functions by timing: Preventive (before) - training, access controls, encryption. Detective (during/after) - monitoring, alerts, audits. Corrective (after) - patching, restoration. Deterrent (influences threat actor) - warnings, cameras.

decision_points.title: Control Type Classification
decision_points.context: Now classify the same training control by implementation type (how it's implemented).
decision_points.question: What TYPE of control is security awareness training?

options.text: Technical - it uses technology
options.feedback: While training might be delivered via technology (LMS, videos), the control itself operates through people - it changes human behavior. Technical controls operate through technology systems (firewalls, encryption). Training is about educating people.
options.consequence: Your manager notes: 'The delivery mechanism doesn't define the control type.'

options.text: Administrative - it operates through people and processes
options.feedback: Correct! Training is an administrative (managerial) control - it operates by influencing human behavior through education and awareness. Administrative controls include policies, procedures, training, background checks, and access reviews - all people-and-process focused.
options.consequence: Your manager confirms: 'Administrative controls work through people, not technology.'

options.text: Physical - it protects physical assets
options.feedback: Physical controls protect tangible assets and spaces - locks, fences, guards, badges. Training protects through education, not physical barriers.
options.consequence: Physical controls are tangible protective measures.

options.text: Hybrid - it combines multiple types
options.feedback: While some controls are hybrid, training is squarely administrative. It's human-focused and process-based. The goal is changing employee behavior through education - a people-centric approach.
options.consequence: Training is fundamentally about people, making it administrative.

hints.text: Technical = technology. Administrative = people/process. Physical = tangible. What does training target?
Training changes human behavior through education - that's administrative (people-focused), not technical.

decision_points.learning_note: Control types: Technical (technology-enforced) - MFA, firewalls, encryption. Administrative (people/process) - policies, training, background checks. Physical (tangible) - locks, badges, guards. Controls can have multiple functions (firewall = preventive + detective) but usually one primary type.

decision_points.title: Complete Control Classification
decision_points.context: Your manager asks you to fully classify this control: 'Motion-activated cameras record all access to the server room, with footage reviewed daily by security staff.'
decision_points.question: How should this control be classified by FUNCTION and TYPE?

options.text: Preventive + Physical - cameras prevent unauthorized access to physical spaces
options.feedback: Cameras don't prevent access - they record it. Someone can still walk into the server room; the camera captures footage. The prevention aspect (if any) is psychological deterrence, not physical prevention. Locks prevent; cameras detect.
options.consequence: Think about what the camera actually does - does it stop entry or record entry?

options.text: Detective + Physical - cameras detect unauthorized access through physical monitoring
options.feedback: Excellent! Function: Detective - the camera records events for later review, detecting unauthorized access. Type: Physical - it's a tangible device protecting physical space. The daily review is the detective activity identifying incidents.
options.consequence: Perfect classification - detective function (identifies incidents), physical type (tangible device).

options.text: Deterrent + Technical - cameras use technology to discourage threats
options.feedback: Cameras can have deterrent effect, but the scenario describes recording and daily review - that's detection, not deterrence. Also, while cameras use technology, they're categorized as physical controls because they protect physical spaces.
options.consequence: The control description emphasizes recording and review (detective), not discouraging threats (deterrent).

options.text: Corrective + Administrative - footage helps correct security issues
options.feedback: Corrective controls fix problems after detection. Cameras detect - they don't fix anything. Also, cameras are physical devices, not administrative (people/process) controls. The review process is administrative, but the camera itself is physical.
options.consequence: Cameras record; they don't correct. Detection comes before correction.

hints.text: What does the camera DO? Record for review = detection. What IS the camera? Physical device.
Detective controls identify incidents (recording + review). Physical controls are tangible (cameras, locks).

decision_points.learning_note: Classifying controls: First identify FUNCTION (what it does - prevent, detect, correct, deter). Then identify TYPE (how implemented - technical, administrative, physical). A camera is Detective (records for review) + Physical (tangible device). Controls can have secondary functions - cameras also deter.

decision_points.title: Defense in Depth Application
decision_points.context: You're reviewing the bank's data center security and need to recommend controls for defense in depth. Currently, badge readers control data center entry.
decision_points.question: Which combination BEST implements defense in depth for data center access?

options.text: Add a second badge reader for redundancy
options.feedback: A second badge reader is just redundancy of the same control, not defense in depth. If badges are compromised or shared, two readers don't help. Defense in depth requires different types of controls that address different attack vectors.
options.consequence: Your manager notes that redundancy isn't the same as layered defense.

options.text: Badge reader + security camera + visitor log + security awareness training
options.feedback: Excellent defense in depth! Multiple control types: Physical (badge, camera), Administrative (visitor log, training), Multiple functions: Preventive (badge), Detective (camera, log), Preventive (training). Each layer addresses different threats and failure modes.
options.consequence: Your manager approves: 'Layered controls - if one fails, others provide protection.'

options.text: Replace badge with biometric only - it's more secure
options.feedback: Biometrics may be stronger than badges, but replacing one control with another isn't defense in depth. Defense in depth layers multiple controls. Also, biometrics have their own weaknesses - what if the reader fails?
options.consequence: Substitution isn't layering. What happens if the biometric reader malfunctions?

options.text: Add three more badge readers at different entrance points
options.feedback: More entry points with the same control type doesn't create defense in depth. If badges can be stolen or cloned, having them at multiple doors doesn't help. You need different control types, not more of the same.
options.consequence: Multiple doors with the same vulnerability isn't layered security.

hints.text: Defense in depth = multiple layers of different control types. Same control repeated isn't layered.
Effective layering: different types (technical, administrative, physical) AND different functions (prevent, detect).

decision_points.learning_note: Defense in depth principles: 1) Multiple layers - no single point of failure, 2) Different control types - if physical fails, administrative may catch it, 3) Different functions - preventive + detective together, 4) Complementary coverage - each layer addresses what others might miss.

decision_points.title: Policy Writing
decision_points.context: You're drafting an information classification policy. Your first attempt reads: 'All employees should try to label documents appropriately when they remember to do so.'
decision_points.question: What's wrong with this policy statement?

options.text: It's too short - policies need to be longer and more detailed
options.feedback: Length isn't the issue. Policies can be concise if they're clear and authoritative. The problem is the language - 'should try' and 'when they remember' make it optional and vague.
options.consequence: Your manager points to the specific wording, not the length.

options.text: It uses weak, non-mandatory language ('should try', 'when they remember') making compliance optional
options.feedback: Exactly right. Policy language must be mandatory and unambiguous. 'Should try' and 'when they remember' create loopholes. Better: 'All employees MUST classify and label documents at the time of creation according to the Data Classification Standard.'
options.consequence: Your manager helps you revise: 'MUST classify' instead of 'should try.'

options.text: It mentions employees - policies should only address systems, not people
options.feedback: Policies absolutely should address people - employee responsibilities are core to security policy. Administrative controls are people-focused. The issue is the weak language, not mentioning employees.
options.consequence: People are essential to policies. The problem is HOW they're addressed.

options.text: It's perfect - policies should be flexible and not too demanding
options.feedback: Policies establish requirements - they need to be clear about what's mandatory. 'Flexible' policy language leads to inconsistent compliance. When something is required (like classification), the policy must say so clearly.
options.consequence: Examiners will cite unclear policies that don't establish clear requirements.

hints.text: What happens if an employee reads 'should try' and decides not to try? Is that a violation?
Policy language: 'must', 'shall', 'will' = mandatory. 'Should', 'may', 'try' = optional. Requirements need mandatory language.

decision_points.learning_note: Policy language matters: Mandatory terms - must, shall, will, required. Optional terms - should, may, can, recommended. If compliance is required, use mandatory language. If it's truly optional, consider making it a guideline instead of policy.

decision_points.title: Standard Development
decision_points.context: The classification policy you wrote says: 'All data must be classified according to sensitivity.' Now you need to write a standard that supports this policy.
decision_points.question: Which is the BEST example of a supporting standard?

options.text: 'Employees should use good judgment when classifying data.'
options.feedback: 'Good judgment' is vague and unenforceable - what does it mean? Standards must be specific and measurable. An auditor can't assess compliance with 'good judgment.' Standards define concrete requirements.
options.consequence: Your manager asks: 'How would we audit compliance with 'good judgment'?'

options.text: 'Data shall be classified as Public, Internal, Confidential, or Restricted based on sensitivity and regulatory requirements.'
options.feedback: This is a proper standard - it specifies the exact classification levels required. It's measurable (is data labeled as one of these four?), enforceable, and supports the policy's intent. Standards translate policy into specific requirements.
options.consequence: Your manager approves: 'Now we have specific, auditable requirements.'

options.text: 'Step 1: Open the document. Step 2: Click File > Properties. Step 3: Select classification level.'
options.feedback: This is a procedure, not a standard. It tells HOW to apply classification, not WHAT the classification requirements are. Standards define the requirements; procedures show how to implement them.
options.consequence: This is useful as a procedure but doesn't define the classification requirements.

options.text: 'Data classification is important for protecting sensitive information.'
options.feedback: This is just a statement about importance - it doesn't set any requirements. Standards must specify WHAT is required, not just why something matters. There's no compliance criteria here.
options.consequence: A statement about importance isn't a requirement.

hints.text: Standards answer 'What specifically is required?' They should be concrete and auditable.
Good standards have specific criteria that can be measured: Are there exactly four classification levels? Yes/No = auditable.

decision_points.learning_note: Standards characteristics: Specific (defines exact requirements), Measurable (compliance can be assessed), Actionable (tells what to do, not how), Traceable (links to policy), Enforceable (violations can be identified). A standard should enable yes/no compliance assessment.

decision_points.title: Framework Alignment
decision_points.context: The examiner asks how your policies align with regulatory requirements. You need to demonstrate framework mapping.
decision_points.question: What is the PRIMARY purpose of mapping controls to frameworks like GLBA or PCI DSS?

options.text: To have impressive documentation that looks professional
options.feedback: Framework mapping isn't about appearances - it's about demonstrating compliance and ensuring coverage. Mappings must be accurate and substantive, not just impressive-looking.
options.consequence: Examiners verify mappings are accurate, not just that they exist.

options.text: To demonstrate compliance with regulatory requirements and ensure complete coverage
options.feedback: Exactly right. Framework mapping serves two purposes: demonstrating to regulators/auditors that requirements are met, and internally ensuring no requirements are missed. It's a completeness check and compliance evidence.
options.consequence: Your manager shows you the compliance matrix linking each control to its regulatory requirement.

options.text: To replace the need for actual security controls with documentation
options.feedback: Documentation never replaces implementation. Mapping shows WHERE controls meet requirements; you still need actual working controls. Auditors verify implementation, not just documentation.
options.consequence: Mapping without implementation fails every audit.

options.text: To satisfy one framework and automatically comply with all others
options.feedback: Frameworks overlap but aren't identical. GLBA and PCI DSS have different requirements. Mapping helps identify where controls satisfy multiple frameworks, but you must verify each framework's specific requirements.
options.consequence: Your manager notes that each framework must be assessed individually, though there are efficiencies.

hints.text: Why do auditors ask for framework mappings? What are they trying to verify?
Mapping demonstrates compliance coverage - which controls satisfy which requirements. It's evidence AND completeness validation.

decision_points.learning_note: Framework mapping benefits: 1) Compliance evidence for auditors, 2) Gap identification - spots unmapped requirements, 3) Efficiency - shows where one control satisfies multiple frameworks, 4) Communication - helps stakeholders understand control purpose. Common approach: Control-to-requirement matrix.

decision_points.title: Compensating Controls
decision_points.context: The legacy teller system cannot support MFA due to technical limitations. The vendor has no timeline for adding MFA support. An examiner asks how you're addressing this gap.
decision_points.question: What is the CORRECT approach to address this control gap?

options.text: Accept the risk - some systems just can't meet modern requirements
options.feedback: For a required control like MFA (especially for financial systems), simply accepting risk isn't sufficient. You need compensating controls that provide equivalent protection. Risk acceptance should be last resort after compensating controls.
options.consequence: The examiner notes that MFA is required and risk acceptance alone won't satisfy the finding.

options.text: Implement compensating controls: restrict system to internal network, require strong passwords, implement session monitoring, and document risk acceptance with timeline for system replacement
options.feedback: Excellent. Compensating controls provide alternative protection when the primary control isn't feasible: network restriction limits exposure, strong passwords partially compensate, monitoring detects misuse, and documented risk acceptance with remediation timeline shows governance. This is proper compensating control implementation.
options.consequence: The examiner accepts the compensating controls with documented risk acceptance and remediation plan.

options.text: Claim MFA is implemented because users have to enter a username AND password (two factors)
options.feedback: Username and password are both 'something you know' - that's single-factor authentication, not MFA. Multi-factor requires different factor types: something you know + something you have/are. This misrepresentation would likely result in audit findings.
options.consequence: The examiner identifies this as a misunderstanding of MFA and notes it as a finding.

options.text: Disable the legacy system until MFA can be implemented
options.feedback: This might be appropriate in extreme cases, but disabling a critical teller system stops bank operations. Compensating controls allow continued operation while managing risk. The goal is security AND business continuity.
options.consequence: Disabling the teller system would shut down branch operations - not practical.

hints.text: Compensating controls provide alternative protection when the primary control isn't feasible. What could reduce MFA's absence risk?
Compensating controls should: reduce the same risk, be documented with rationale, include timeline for proper remediation when possible.

decision_points.learning_note: Compensating control requirements: 1) Address the same risk as the original requirement, 2) Provide similar level of defense, 3) Be documented with rationale, 4) Include risk acceptance approved by management, 5) Have remediation timeline when feasible. Compensating controls are temporary - work toward proper implementation.

decision_points.title: Policy Review and Maintenance
decision_points.context: Your manager asks you to establish a policy maintenance schedule. The bank's current policies haven't been reviewed since they were written.
decision_points.question: What is the appropriate policy review and maintenance approach?

options.text: Review policies only when auditors require it
options.feedback: Reactive review leaves policies stale and potentially non-compliant between audits. Threats, regulations, and business needs change constantly. Policies should be proactively maintained, not just auditor-driven.
options.consequence: Auditors note that reactive-only review results in outdated, ineffective policies.

options.text: Annual review of all policies, plus ad-hoc review when regulations, threats, or business needs change significantly
options.feedback: Excellent maintenance approach. Annual reviews ensure systematic coverage. Ad-hoc reviews respond to changes - new regulations, major incidents, business changes. This combination keeps policies current and relevant while not being burdensome.
options.consequence: Your manager implements annual review cycles with triggers for ad-hoc reviews documented.

options.text: Monthly review of all policies to ensure they're always current
options.feedback: Monthly review of all policies is excessive for most organizations. Policies don't change that frequently, and constant review creates change fatigue without adding value. Annual with ad-hoc triggers is more practical.
options.consequence: Monthly reviews prove unsustainable - stakeholders stop engaging meaningfully.

options.text: Review policies every five years - they shouldn't change often
options.feedback: Five years is far too long. Threats evolve, regulations change, technology advances. A five-year-old security policy is likely significantly outdated and may expose the organization to compliance findings and security risks.
options.consequence: The five-year-old policies the bank currently has are exactly why examiners cited documentation issues.

hints.text: Balance is key - not too frequent (burdensome), not too rare (outdated). What events should trigger review?
Industry standard: Annual systematic review + ad-hoc when triggered by regulatory changes, incidents, or business changes.

decision_points.learning_note: Policy maintenance best practices: 1) Annual comprehensive review of all policies, 2) Ad-hoc review triggers: regulatory changes, major incidents, business changes, audit findings, 3) Version control and change documentation, 4) Stakeholder review and approval workflow, 5) Communication of changes to affected parties.

summary_teaching_points: Policy hierarchy: Policies (what/why) â†’ Standards (what specifically) â†’ Procedures (how) â†’ Guidelines (suggestions)
Control functions: Preventive (before), Detective (during/after), Corrective (after), Deterrent (discourages), Compensating (alternative)
Defense in depth requires different control types and functions, not just multiple instances of the same control
Policy language matters: 'must' and 'shall' are mandatory; 'should' and 'may' are optional
Standards must be specific, measurable, and auditable
Framework mapping demonstrates compliance and ensures complete coverage
Compensating controls address the same risk when primary controls aren't feasible
Policies require regular review (annual minimum) plus ad-hoc review when conditions change
